Notes: "Effective March 7, 2022:    Travel Requirements for: Visitors Arriving by Air    All visitors to Bermuda 2 years old and up are required to have an approved Travel Authorisation to enter Bermuda. Children under 2 years old do not need to apply for a Travel Authorisation.  All Bermuda visitors arriving by air aged 12 and older must be fully vaccinated.  ...  Fully Vaccinated Travellers 12 years and over: COVID-19 NAAT (PCR, LAMP or TMA) test up to 4 days before arrival OR Supervised antigen up to 2 days before arrival"    Source: https://archive.ph/XvKGc
No changes found to established relief programs and Economic Recovery Plan.    Source: https://archive.ph/7eKKo  Source: https://archive.ph/EplWg

Good government website    Source: https://archive.ph/dgoa8
Testing available for symptomatic, asymptomatic, and travellers.    Updated June 17, 2022  Source: https://archive.ph/EM1R3

"A person who tests positive must disclose their close contacts. These are the instructions the positive case must follow:  - Identify and notify all persons you have been in close contact with that they must separate from others since they were last in close contact with you ...  - A Close contact is a person who has touched you (e.g. for a hug) or has been closer than 6 feet from you for 15 minutes or more ..."    There is also an "automated notification email process for notifying COVID positive patients and named close contacts of their status and their need to isolate or quarantine."    Updated June 14th 2022  Source: https://archive.ph/Sc9dr

"From 31 March 2022, you must wear a face mask indoors when:    - travelling by bus, ferry (excluding the outdoor decks), taxi, limousine or minibus â both passengers and operators,  - working in or visiting health service providers such as a doctors or dentists, nurses, physiotherapists, occupational therapists, etc., health services, such as a hospital, dental facility, laboratory, residential care facility etc. and,  - visiting or working at Corrections facilities, and  - inside the L. F. Wade International Airport building."    Source: https://archive.ph/dgoa8

"Vaccines are offered to Bermudaâs residents who meet the following criteria:  - Patients aged 5 to 11 years old are eligible for a 1st or 2nd dose only. The time between doses must be at least 21 days.  - Patients aged 12 and above are eligible for 1st, 2nd or 3rd dose. The time between the 1st and 2nd dose must be at least 21 days. The time between the 2nd dose and 3rd dose booster must be at least 5 months.  - Residents 50 years or older, and immunocompromised residents are eligible for a 4th dose of the COVID-19 vaccine provided their 3rd dose was at least 5 months ago."    From FAQ: "Is there a cost to get the vaccine? The vaccine will be provided by the Government of Bermuda at no cost."    Updated: June 12th, 2022  Source: https://archive.ph/OS9rx

27 june 2022 is the start of the last week of the regular elementary and secondary school year in most Canadian jurisdictions, the national news service sums up âa topsy-turvy school year warped by the COVID-19 crisis. Many Canadian students cautiously returned to class this fall [of 2021] under strict pandemic protocols, such as mandatory masking and social distancing. As younger kids became eligible for vaccination late last year, it seemed like schools were settling into new routines. That was soon upended by the rampant spread of the Omicron variant, which saw some provinces extend winter breaks or switch to remote learning. Following the winter surge, public health measures were eased, allowing students to ditch their masks and gather together for school events.â Some post-secondary institutions are still requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. However, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated by governments. See Toronto Star newspaper and University Affairs Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220626203022/https://www.universityaffairs.ca/news/news-article/covid-19-updates-for-canadas-universities/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220626203205/https://www.thestar.com/life/2022/06/26/from-closures-to-near-normal-routines-students-look-back-on-covid-warped-school-year.html

On 4 july 2022, Canadian elementary and secondary schools as well as post-secondary educational institutions are relatively inactive with only a small percentage of students taking summer courses â some in-person and some online. Some post-secondary institutions are still requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. However, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated by governments. No jurisdiction has any covid-related measures in place at any level of education. See University Affairs Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220704195353/https://www.universityaffairs.ca/news/news-article/covid-19-updates-for-canadas-universities/

On 13 june 2022 the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada continues to recommend: âStaying home and keeping away from others if you test positive or are experiencing any symptoms, even if mildâ. The  âany symptoms, even if mildâ component of this recommendation is broader and more prescriptive than previous advice at the end of 2021: âstay at home when you're sick â¦ Be prepared to stay at home if you have symptomsâ. Some sub-national jurisdictions are not following the national governmentâs recommendation and have ended isolation rules for covid-positive patients. However, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canadaâs recommendation is available to all Canadians. See government of Canada and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220609110636/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220509133204/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/manitoba-covid-19-isolation-requirement-personal-care-home-1.6376095

The government of Canada announced that âon June 20, 2022, the vaccination requirement to board a plane or a train in Canada will be suspendedâ¦ Due to the unique nature of cruise ship travel, vaccination requirements for passengers and crew of cruise ships will continue to remain in effect.â There are some commercial domestic cruises solely within Canada. Unvaccinated persons who wish to travel â e.g., from Quebec City to Montreal or a destination in Ontario â can now do so by air or rail, even if their first preference to travel by commercial boat cruise remains unavailable. For most consumers, the principal appeals of a commercial boat cruise â dining, accommodation and sightseeing â outweigh traveling from one city to another. The removal of the vaccine mandate for domestic air and rail passengers means that travel within Canada is open to both vaccinated and unvaccinated persons. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220618114425/https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/news/2022/06/suspension-of-the-vaccine-mandates-for-domestic-travellers-transportation-workers-and-federal-employees.html

This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.â Note that some sub-national governments have shifted to a âliving with covidâ approach with lower-profile and/or less frequent public communication emphasizing individual risk management. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220704120630/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse.html

On 11 july 2022, the government of Canada continues with a ânational public education campaign that provides Canadians with evidence-based information on COVID-19, and encourages behaviours that protect individuals and our communities. This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.â Note that some sub-national governments have shifted to a âliving with covidâ approach with lower-profile and/or less frequent public communication emphasizing individual responsibility for risk management. While some sub-national government approaches are no longer consistent with the national governmentâs information campaign, 2G still warranted due to the national scope of Government of Canada public outreach efforts. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220711185421/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse.html

On 13 june 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. E.g., according to a recent media report: âthe rise of the highly transmissible Omicron variantâ¦ prompted governments to shift reliance from government-backed PCR testing to the mass distribution of rapid antigen tests Â­â the results of which are less accurate and are largely not collected by health authoritiesâ. See Governments of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220605105043/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220614104939/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/technology/article-ottawa-expected-to-shut-down-national-covid-19-contact-tracing-app/

On 20 june 2022, government of Canada advises that when individuals âtest positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.â Most provinces and territories intend to follow this practice, if conditions and resources permit. However, tracing capacity is not sufficient in most jurisdictions to deal with high case numbers. In most cases, contact tracing responsibility is up to individuals who are symptomatic and/or have tested positive. For example, in Canadaâs most populous province of Ontario: âIf you have symptoms of COVID-19 or have tested positive, tell your close contacts that they have been exposedâ¦ Informing your contact will help stop the spread of the virus. Give them the link to this webpage, ontario.ca/exposed, so they can protect themselves and their contacts.â See Governments of Canada and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220617235453/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620132340/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/exposed

On 18 june 2022: âPublic transit users in Quebec are no longer required to wear masks â¦ Masks are still mandatory in hospitals, long-term care homes and other health-care facilities.â In Canadaâs most populous province: âOntarioâs COVID-19 mask mandates â¦ long-term care and retirement homesâ. The Government of Canada continues to regulate mask-wearing to be mandatory for all persons in airports, commercial airplanes and trains on inter-provincial networks. See Government of Canada and Toronto Star newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620133702/https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2022/06/18/covid-19-quebec-lifts-mask-mandate-for-public-transit-users.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620133232/https://www.thestar.com/local-oshawa/opinion/2022/06/19/why-you-still-need-to-be-masked-while-at-lakeridge-health.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620172914/https://tc.canada.ca/en/initiatives/covid-19-measures-updates-guidance-issued-transport-canada/covid-19-information-travellers-within-canada

Masks are still mandatory in hospitals, long-term care homes and other health-care facilities in most jurisdictions. Ontarioâs mask mandate is limited to long-term care and retirement homes. Effective 20 june 2022, the Canadian governmentâs âPolicy on COVID-19 Vaccination for the Core Public Administration (CPA) Including the Royal Canadian Mounted Police will be suspendedâ¦they will no longer be required to be vaccinated as a condition of employment. As such, employees who are on administrative leave without pay for noncompliance with the Policy in force until now will be contacted by their managers to arrange their return to regular work duties.  Crown corporations and separate agencies will also be asked to suspend vaccine requirements, and the vaccination requirement for supplier personnel accessing federal government workplaces will also be suspended. With the suspension of vaccination requirements, employees placed on unpaid leave may return to work. ...In addition, federally regulated transport sector employers will no longer be required to have mandatory vaccination policies in place for employees. Due to the unique nature of cruise ship travel, vaccination requirements for passengers and crew of cruise ships will continue to remain in effect.â For the military: âThe [Canadian Armed Forces] CAF is currently assessing the need for â¦ the [Chief of Defence Staff] CDS Directives on COVID-19 Vaccinationâ¦ the CDS Directives remain in effect until further noticeâ. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220618114425/https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/news/2022/06/suspension-of-the-vaccine-mandates-for-domestic-travellers-transportation-workers-and-federal-employees.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220619171339/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-national-defence/maple-leaf/defence/2022/06/message-suspension-mandatory-vaccination-federal-government-employees.html

On June 12, 2022, the US changed its requirement for negative tests.     "As of 12:01AM ET on June 12, 2022, CDC will no longer require air passengers traveling from a foreign country to the United States to show a negative COVID-19 viral test or documentation of recovery from COVID-19 before they board their flight. For more information, see Rescission: Requirement for Negative Pre-Departure COVID-19 Test Result or Documentation of Recovery from COVID-19 for all Airline or Other Aircraft Passengers Arriving into the United States from Any Foreign Country."    However, this does not result in a change in stringency level as (1) international passengers are still required to be vaccinated and (2) vaccination check is considered a form of screening.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220612074246/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel/index.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20220613044024/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/proof-of-vaccination.html

Per the USA government guidance on employment benefits, "The federal government allowed states to change their laws to provide COVID-19 unemployment benefits for people whose jobs have been affected by the coronavirus pandemic."    See archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220605014140/https://www.usa.gov/unemployment
Debt and contract relief is not being provided at the federal level.     See archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220611182127/https://www.usa.gov/help-with-bills
The CDC still maintains a robust public information campaign.     See archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220612161104/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-nCoV/index.html
